CLINTON_199_2.intervention:
CLINTON: "which may prove to be an intelligence benefit
we've got to do everything we can to vacuum up intelligence from Europe, from the Middle East
That means we've got to work more closely with our allies, and that's something that Donald has been very dismissive of
We're working with NATO, the longest military alliance in the history of the world, to really turn our attention to terrorism
We're working with our friends in the Middle East, many of which, as you know, are Muslim majority nations
Donald has consistently insulted Muslims abroad, Muslims at home, when we need to be cooperating with Muslim nations and with the American Muslim community
They're on the front lines
They can provide information to us that we might not get anywhere else
They need to have close working cooperation with law enforcement in these communities, not be alienated and pushed away as some of Donald's rhetoric, unfortunately, has led to"

cqs.cq: Can it be reasonably inferred that working more closely with Muslim-majority nations and communities is inherently incompatible with effective counter-terrorism efforts?
Does working more closely with Muslim-majority nations necessarily depend on Donald's behavior towards Muslims?

Can it be reasonably inferred that the benefits of increased cooperation with Muslim-majority nations and the American Muslim community would outweigh the risks or potential drawbacks, if such cooperation is necessary to counter terrorism?

CLINTON_1_2.intervention:
CLINTON: "If you help create the profits , you should be able to share in them , not just the executives at the top
I want us to do more to support people who are struggling to balance family and work
I 've heard from so many of you about the difficult choices you face and the stresses that you 're under
let 's have paid family leave , earned sick days
Let 's be sure we have affordable child care and debt-free college
How are we going to do it
We 're going to do it by having the wealthy pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes
we tonight are on the stage together , Donald Trump and I
it 's good to be with you
We 're going to have a debate where we are talking about the important issues facing our country
You have to judge us , who can shoulder the immense , awesome responsibilities of the presidency , who can put into action the plans that will make your life better
I hope that I will be able to earn your vote on November 8th"

cqs.cq: Does the claim that 'having the wealthy pay their fair share and close corporate loopholes' is a sufficient plan for implementing paid family leave, earned sick days, affordable child care, and debt-free college?

How can Clinton's proposal for higher taxes on the wealthy and closing corporate loopholes be reconciled with his statement that he wants to 'put into action the plans' that will make people's lives better, if those plans require a more favorable business environment?

Does Clinton's promise that closing corporate loopholes will directly lead to implementing paid family leave, earned sick days, affordable child care, and debt-free college without specifying how the increased revenue from closing these loopholes would be allocated?

CLINTON_21.intervention:
CLINTON: "nine million people lost their jobs
Five million people lost their homes
$ 13 trillion in family wealth was wiped out
Now , we have come back from that abyss
it has not been easy
we 're now on the precipice of having a potentially much better economy
the last thing we need to do is to go back to the policies that failed us in the first place
Independent experts have looked at what I 've proposed
looked at what Donald 's proposed
I intend to get it done
Take clean energy
Some country is going to be the clean- energy superpower of the 21st century
Donald thinks that climate change is a hoax perpetrated by the Chinese
I think it 's real"

cqs.cq: How can Clinton's assurance that independent experts have evaluated and endorsed his clean energy plan be trusted, given that these experts also assessed Donald's proposal?

How can Clinton's assertion that his proposed policies will lead to a 'potentially much better economy' be justified if independent experts have not been shown to agree with the economic projections of both his and Donald's proposals?
How can we be certain that Clinton's proposed policies, which have been vetted by independent experts, will not produce the same economic problems as those of his predecessor?

CLINTON_223_1.intervention:
CLINTON: "Let 's talk about two important issues that were briefly mentioned by Donald
first , NATO
NATO as a military alliance has something called Article 5
you know the only time it 's ever been invoked ?
After 9/11 , when the 28 nations of NATO said that they would go to Afghanistan with us to fight terrorism
something that they still are doing by our side
With respect to Iran , when I became secretary of state , Iran was weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb
They had mastered the nuclear fuel cycle under the Bush administration
They had built covert facilities
They had stocked them with centrifuges that were whirling away
we had sanctioned them"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's argument about NATO invoking Article 5 only after 9/11 imply that the alliance would not have acted if a Democrat were president?
Does invoking Article 5 after a significant event, such as 9/11, demonstrate the NATO alliance's readiness and willingness to respond collectively in times of crisis?
What specific evidence or credible sources does Clinton claim to support his assertion that NATO invoked Article 5 after 9/11, and what is the nature of this evidence's reliability?

CLINTON_223_2.intervention:
CLINTON: "I voted for every sanction against Iran when I was in the Senate
it was n't enough
I spent a year-and-a-half putting together a coalition that included Russia and China to impose the toughest sanctions on Iran
 we did drive them to the negotiating table
my successor , John Kerry , and President Obama got a deal that put a lid on Iran 's nuclear program without firing a single shot
That 's diplomacy
That 's coalition-building
That 's working with other nations
That 's not good judgment"

cqs.cq: Is Clinton's assessment of his own diplomatic efforts, which included cooperation with countries like Russia and China, a fair representation of the actual outcomes and challenges faced during those negotiations?

Does Clinton's argument that she was able to achieve a successful diplomatic outcome without firing a single shot imply that her previous support for sanctions against Iran might not have had any significant negative consequences?

Does Clinton's claim that his actions as Senator directly led to a negotiated deal with Iran, without any mention of subsequent policies or actions taken by his successors, accurately reflect the complexity and effectiveness of diplomatic efforts?

CLINTON_225.intervention: CLINTON: "That is not the right temperament to be commander-in- chief , to be taunted"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's assertion that a certain temperament is incompatible with being commander-in-chief rely on a definition of 'commander-in-chief' that is not widely accepted or commonly understood?
Is the claim about the president's temperament being relevant to their ability to command respect and lead effectively?
What specific behaviors or incidents led Clinton to claim that a certain temperament would be unsuitable for commander-in-chief?

CLINTON_231.intervention:
CLINTON: "in fact , his cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons is so deeply troubling
That is the number-one threat we face in the world
it becomes particularly threatening if terrorists ever get their hands on any nuclear material"

cqs.cq: How does Clinton's assertion that the number-one threat we face in the world is a cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons translate into concrete, verifiable evidence of this attitude?

How can a cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons, as described by Clinton, be considered the number-one threat we face in the world without any further specification or evidence of the nature of this threat?
Can we be certain that the speaker's assessment of the threat posed by nuclear weapons is not influenced by a personal bias or emotional response rather than objective analysis?

CLINTON_235.intervention:
CLINTON: "It 's a good one , though
It well describes the problem"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's endorsement of the description imply that he has actually identified and understood the problem it is describing?
Does Clinton's statement adequately acknowledge the solution to the problem described?
Is this description of the problem sufficient to justify the endorsement of the proposed solution?

CLINTON_244_2.intervention:
CLINTON: "If he 's going to criticize a deal that has been very successful in giving us access to Iranian facilities that we never had before , then he should tell us what his alternative would be
it 's like his plan to defeat ISIS
the only secret is that he has no plan
He says it 's a secret plan
we need to be more precise in how we talk about these issues
People around the word follow our presidential campaigns so closely , trying to get hints about what we will do
Can they rely on us ?
Are we going to lead the world with strength and in accordance with our values ?
That 's what I intend to do
I intend to be a leader of our country that people can count on , both here at home and around the world
to make decisions that will further peace and prosperity
also stand up to bullies , whether they 're abroad or at home
We can not let those who would try to destabilize the world to interfere with American interests and security"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's criticism of his opponent's lack of a clear plan for defeating ISIS actually provide any evidence that he has a better plan himself?

Does Clinton's statement about having no plan for defeating ISIS qualify as a legitimate criticism of his opponent, or is it an attempt to deflect scrutiny and create a false dichotomy between criticizing the existing deal and proposing a vague 'secret plan'?
Does Clinton's claim that he has no plan for defeating ISIS necessarily mean that his alternative plans are also ineffective or unworkable?

CLINTON_25.intervention:
CLINTON: "it 's important that we grip this and deal with it , both at home and abroad
here 's what we can do
We can deploy a half a billion more solar panels
We can have enough clean energy to power every home
We can build a new modern electric grid
That 's a lot of jobs
that 's a lot of new economic activity
 I 've tried to be very specific about what we can and should do
I am determined that we 're going to get the economy really moving again , building on the progress we 've made over the last eight years , but never going back to what got us in trouble in the first place"

cqs.cq: How does Clinton's proposal for a massive increase in solar panels and electric grid construction address the underlying causes of economic stagnation, rather than just treating its symptoms?
Does deploying a half billion more solar panels and building a new modern electric grid necessarily lead to the economy 'getting really moving again'?
How can deploying a half billion more solar panels, assuming it is technologically feasible and financially sustainable, actually address the economic issues that led to trouble in the first place?

CLINTON_37.intervention:
CLINTON: " Some of them I voted for
The biggest one, a multinational one known as CAFTA, I voted against
I hold the same standards as I look at all of these trade deals
let's not assume that trade is the only challenge we have in the economy
it is a part of it
I'm going to have a special prosecutor
We're going to enforce the trade deals we have, and we're going to hold people accountable
When I was secretary of state, we actually increased American exports globally 30 percent
We increased them to China 50 percent
 know how to really work to get new jobs and to get exports that helped to create more new jobs"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's claim that increasing American exports globally and with China constitutes evidence of her commitment to holding people accountable for enforcing trade deals, given that she voted against a similar trade deal herself?
Does Clinton's claim that she is committed to enforcing trade deals and increasing exports necessarily imply that she supports all existing trade agreements, including CAFTA?
Does Clinton's assertion that she holds 'the same standards' for all trade deals imply that her approval of CAFTA is consistent with those standards?

CLINTON_39.intervention:
CLINTON: "I've been a senator, Donald
...
You haven't done it.
 I have been a secretary of state
And I have done a lot"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's assertion that his foreign policy experience makes him better qualified for the presidency than Trump, who has never held public office, constitute a logically coherent and non-circular argument?
Is it reasonable to assume that serving as Secretary of State constitutes doing something, when the argument does not provide evidence of its significance or impact?
Is it possible that Clinton's claims about her experience as secretary of state are being compared to Trump's lack thereof, rather than an evaluation of their respective accomplishments?

CLINTON_55.intervention:
CLINTON: "There are different views about what's good for our country, our economy, and our leadership in the world
it's important to look at what we need to do to get the economy going again
new jobs with rising incomes, investments, not in more tax cuts that would add $5 trillion to the debt"

cqs.cq: What makes Clinton's proposal for economic recovery uniquely better than alternative solutions that involve more tax cuts?
Does Clinton's proposal for new jobs, investments, and reduced tax cuts not infringe on individual freedoms or constitutional protections?
Does Clinton's proposal for addressing economic concerns rely on empirical data rather than simply opposing tax cuts?

CLINTON_57.intervention:
CLINTON: "you have no plan
I have written a book about it. It's called "Stronger Together."
You can pick it up tomorrow at a bookstore
we need to have strong growth , fair growth , sustained growth
We also have to look at how we help families balance the responsibilities at home and the responsibilities at business
we have a very robust set of plans
people have looked at both of our plans , have concluded that mine would create 10 million jobs and yours would lose us 3.5 million jobs , and explode the debt which would have a recession"

cqs.cq: How can the validity of Clinton's plan be determined if it is based solely on an opposing book, rather than a publicly available and peer-reviewed document?

Does Clinton's assertion that his book provides an unbiased assessment of his plan, given that experts have concluded a significant disparity between their plans, actually provide evidence for the accuracy of his claim?
How can Clinton's reliance on a book as evidence of his comprehensive plan be considered sufficient to address concerns about its feasibility and potential consequences?

CLINTON_66.intervention:
CLINTON: "what I have proposed would not add a penny to the debt
 your plans would add $ 5 trillion to the debt
What I have proposed would cut regulations and streamline them for small businesses
What I have proposed would be paid for by raising taxes on the wealthy
they have made all the gains in the economy
it 's time that the wealthy and corporations paid their fair share to support this country"

cqs.cq: How can Clinton's plan to raise taxes on the wealthy be considered fair when many of the wealthy individuals and corporations have seen their wealth increase significantly over the past few decades, despite not contributing proportionally more to the economy than average citizens?
Does raising taxes on the wealthy guarantee that they will actually pay their fair share, or could this simply lead to tax evasion and further economic distortions?
How can raising taxes on the wealthy be expected to increase revenue if it is alleged that they have made all the gains in the economy?

CLINTON_6_1.intervention:
CLINTON: "we are 5 percent of the world 's population ; we have to trade with the other 95 percent
we need to have smart , fair trade deals
We also , though , need to have a tax system that rewards work and not just financial transactions
the kind of plan that Donald has put forth would be trickle-down economics all over again
it would be the most extreme version , the biggest tax cuts for the top percent of the people in this country than we 've ever had
trumped-up trickle-down , because that 's exactly what it would be
That is not how we grow the economy
We just have a different view about what 's best for growing the economy , how we make investments that will actually produce jobs and rising incomes
we come at it from somewhat different perspectives
Donald was very fortunate in his life , and that 's all to his benefit"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's assertion that Donald Trump's economic plan would be equivalent to 'trickle-down economics all over again' accurately reflect the key differences in their proposed tax policies?

Is Clinton's assertion that Trump's tax plan would be the most extreme version of trickle-down economics actually supported by evidence, rather than relying on anecdotal observations about Trump's personal life?

How can it be concluded that Donald Trump's economic plan is based on trickle-down economics when Clinton mentions 'trump-up trickle-down' as a criticism, implying that the term is being used in a derogatory manner to describe Trump's views?

CLINTON_6_2.intervention:
CLINTON: "He started his business with $ 14 million , borrowed from his father
he really believes that the more you help wealthy people , the better off we 'll be and that everything will work out from there
I do n't buy that
I have a different experience
My father was a small-businessman
He worked really hard
He printed drapery fabrics on long tables, where he pulled out those fabrics and he went down with a silkscreen and dumped the paint in and took the squeegee and kept going
what I believe is the more we can do for the middle class, the more we can invest in you, your education, your skills, your future
the better we will be off and the better we'll grow
That's the kind of economy I want us to see again"

cqs.cq: How does Clinton's claim that his personal experience with small business informs his policy stance on helping wealthy people, and vice versa?

Does Clinton's assumption that his personal experience as a small-business owner is representative of the overall business environment, which he claims is dominated by wealthy entrepreneurs who believe in trickle-down economics?
Does the speaker's personal experience as a small-business owner necessarily generalize to the broader economic benefits of helping wealthy individuals, as suggested by their opponent?

CLINTON_85.intervention:
CLINTON: "let 's start the clock again , Lester
We 've looked at your tax proposals
I do n't see changes in the corporate tax rates or the kinds of proposals you 're referring to that would cause the repatriation , bringing back of money that 's stranded overseas
I happen to support that"

cqs.cq: Is it possible for Clinton's statement to be true, given that the repatriation of stranded overseas money is often driven by changes in corporate tax rates?

Does Clinton's dismissal of the repatriation proposals as not causing a change in corporate tax rates adequately address the possibility that some changes, although unintended or unforeseen, might still occur?
Does Clinton's statement accurately reflect his understanding of how repatriation of overseas funds works, given that it typically involves a reduction in corporate tax rates rather than no change?

CLINTON_87.intervention:
CLINTON: "I happen to support that in a way that will actually work to our benefit
when I look at what you have proposed , you have what is called now the Trump loophole
it would so advantage you and the business you do"

cqs.cq: Is Clinton's claim that the proposed solution would only benefit the individual or business he is referring to, and not the general public or the country as a whole, supported by sufficient evidence?

How can Clinton's statement that a proposed policy is called the 'Trump loophole' be used to justify supporting the same policy without providing evidence of how it would actually work to their benefit?
Is Clinton's use of the term 'Trump loophole' a legitimate reference to a specific, well-known concept or is it an ad hominem attack?

CLINTON_92.intervention:
CLINTON: "it is
trumped-up trickle-down
Trickle-down did not work
It got us into the mess we were in , in 2008 and 2009
Slashing taxes on the wealthy has n't worked
a lot of really smart , wealthy people know that
they are saying , hey , we need to do more to make the contributions we should be making to rebuild the middle class
I do n't think top-down works in America
building the middle class , investing in the middle class , making college debt-free so more young people can get their education , helping people refinance their—their debt from college at a lower rate
Those are the kinds of things that will really boost the economy
Broad-based , inclusive growth is what we need in America , not more advantages for people at the very top"

cqs.cq: Does relying solely on broad-based, inclusive growth policies necessarily mean that top-down initiatives to stimulate economic growth are inherently flawed?
Doesn't the fact that Clinton is relying on anecdotal evidence from 'really smart, wealthy people' to support his claims about trickle-down economics undermine the credibility of his argument?

Doesn't Clinton's assumption that trickle-down economics is inherently failed solely because it was used by previous administrations have been unfairly applied and neglect the fact that some iterations of trickle-down policies, such as job creation tax cuts, may still be effective in certain contexts?

CL_57.intervention:
CL: "Well, both sides of the transaction suffer as a result of ignoring moral hazard
because moral hazard is a natural part of the process of lending and borrowing
And if you suppress it, then in fact you're in a situation where the wealth that you look like you're generating is fool’s gold, not real wealth at all."

cqs.cq: Is the existence of moral hazard a sufficient justification for ignoring efforts to manage or mitigate its effects on lending and borrowing transactions?
Does CL's argument that ignoring moral hazard is necessary to generate any wealth at all, imply that there are no alternative measures to mitigate moral hazard?
Does CL's assumption that suppressing moral hazard always leads to fool's gold wealth overlook the possibility of alternative mechanisms generating true wealth?

Doctor-Mom_205.intervention:
Doctor-Mom: "I would support a full ban of peanut products on any airline.
Peanut reactions can be life threatening.
An individual doesn't have to consume the product to have a life threatening reaction.
They can have contact or inhalation reactions.
Restricting to certain flights is not enough,
as residue can be rampant.
Providing buffer zones is a thoughtful gesture,
but from a practical point of view does not work.
With so many food choices available, why are peanuts a necessary choice?
I am a physician , and author on the subject.
I have free food allergy online support forums with 3000 members.
http://www.drmomsallergyrx.com/
I would be more than willing to work with you in any way on this decision making process.
The allergic community is so grateful that you are allowing our voices to be heard.
The decision you are considering could save many lives."

cqs.cq: Does the physician's claim that individuals with peanut allergies can have life-threatening reactions from contact or inhalation pose a risk equal to those who experience anaphylaxis through ingestion of peanuts?
Does the potential reduction in peanut-related incidents on flights justify a blanket ban of peanuts on all airlines, potentially impacting passengers who do not have severe peanut allergies?
Is the concern about peanut products being a necessary choice to begin with, based on their prevalence and impact, proportionate to other food allergens such as tree nuts or shellfish?

Elmattador__92.intervention:
Elmattador: "you must have missed the GOP debates"
 < this message is answering to > 
Bigtwinkie: "This debate has honestly been making me uncomfortable
its been way too hostile
Its like listening to mom and dad fight in the kitchen while your hide under the covers in your room
 all they succeed at is making the entire panel seem unlikable
the democratic nominee will be bleeding votes no matter who wins"

cqs.cq: Does the claim that the Democratic nominee will bleed votes regardless of who wins follow logically from the speaker's description of the GOP debates as 'making the entire panel seem unlikable'?
Is it reasonable to assume that a debate's level of hostility will directly impact the democratic nominee's chances in an election?
Is it reasonable to assume that the Democratic nominee's chances of winning are unaffected by the Republican candidate's performance in a debate, regardless of who wins?

FoodAllergyMom_199_1.intervention:
FoodAllergyMom: "My child is 2 years old and he is severely allergic to peanuts, tree nuts, egg and milk.
My son has reacted to airborne particles from someone opening a bag of nuts near him.
My husband and I used to be world traveler's and dreamed of traveling with our son.
It is heartbreaking to think that our child will not get to experience the world, or if he does it may cost him his life.
What about when he gets older and his job requires him to fly across the country in a weekend?
Should he have to risk his life so he can work in his possible future dream job?
This is a disability, no question about it.
We are talking about being in the air with peanut particles being circulated through the cabin and possible no place to land for hours.
An EpiPen only last 15 minutes.
Peanut allergy is unpredictable.
The first reaction could be mild
and the second could cause your blood pressure to drop like a rocket, your throat to close up and your heart to stop beating."

cqs.cq: Is it reasonable to assume that a person's medical condition will remain constant and predictable throughout their life, regardless of changing circumstances such as age, employment requirements, or access to emergency medical treatment?

Does requiring individuals with severe peanut allergies, such as your son, to carry an EpiPen at all times, like those required in commercial airplanes, infringe upon their right to pursue employment opportunities?

Is it morally justifiable to prioritize one's career goals over the potential risk of a fatal anaphylactic reaction, without considering alternative accommodations or modifications that could mitigate the risk?

Frequent-Flyer_157.intervention:
Frequent-Flyer: "I have sympathy for those with peanut allergies,
but banning peanuts from flights via a DOT regulation seems to go too far.
Perhaps advocacy groups for those who are peanutallergic will approach the major carriers to voluntarily set aside seating blocks that are reserved for allergy sufferers, and nonsufferers who are willing to agree not to eat peanuts while sitting in that particular block.
As someone who suffers from a medical condition which requires me to carry my "rescue" medication with me everywhere I go,
I think that if the risk to an allergy sufferer is deemed to be significant, then they should
consider alternate travel methods other than flying,
ensure they have sufficient "rescue" medication to last the entire time they might be stuck in an aircraft,
they should wear appropriate clothing / face masks to minimize exposed skin and inhalation risk.
Requiring other passengers to forgo their "right" to eat peanuts so as to accommodate the "right" of allergy sufferers to fly seems a bit much,
particularly if the allergy sufferers don't fly often, anyway."

cqs.cq: Does the argument's suggestion that the responsibility for managing peanut exposure on flights should rest solely with allergy sufferers and willing nonsufferers, rather than with airlines or regulatory bodies, seem reasonable?

Does the author's suggestion that passengers with peanut allergies should be required to take precautions and consider alternative travel methods if they pose a risk to others, imply that those without life-threatening allergies have a 'right' to consume peanuts on flights?

Does the speaker's willingness to accommodate the needs of peanut-allergic individuals solely for their own medical condition imply a prioritization of their interests over the potential risks and needs of other passengers?

Glblwrmingisfak__552.intervention:
Glblwrmingisfak: "What argument?
Nobody proposes common sense gun solutions
The DOJ over a decade ago already determined that an assault weapons ban won't do shit for addressing homicide rates in the US
It is not a solution for any of our problems
Bernie should know
he clearly isn't stupid"

cqs.cq: Does Glblwrmingisfak acknowledge that the absence of a proposed common sense gun solution doesn't necessarily mean it's not a viable option?

Does Glblwrmingisfak's assertion that an assault weapons ban is not a solution for addressing homicide rates in the US rely on the DOJ's determination, or does it assume the determination was based on a flawed understanding of the issue?
Does the conclusion that no common sense gun solution can address the US's problems rely on the assumption that an assault weapons ban is a necessary condition for any solution to exist?

HOLT_126.intervention:
HOLT: "Stop-and-frisk was ruled unconstitutional in New York
it largely singled out black and Hispanic young men"

cqs.cq: What is the evidence that the unconstitutional ruling of stop-and-frisk applies exclusively to New York, and not to other jurisdictions where similar policies may have been implemented?
Does Holt's assertion about the racial demographics of those affected by stop-and-frisk policies in New York align with the actual data and evidence presented to support this claim?
Does the fact that stop-and-frisk was ruled unconstitutional in New York necessarily imply that it targeted black and Hispanic young men?

HOLT_239.intervention:
HOLT: "Which leads to my next question
we enter our last segment here on the , still on the subject of securing America
On nuclear weapons , President Obama reportedly considered changing the nation 's longstanding policy on first use
Do you support the current policy ?
Mr. Trump , you have two minutes on that"

cqs.cq: What specific, credible evidence does President Obama's consideration of changing the nation's policy on first use of nuclear weapons provide to warrant a change in the current policy?
What makes President Obama's consideration of changing the nation's policy on first use relevant to whether one supports or opposes the current policy?

Does Holt's proposed discussion of President Obama's policy change on nuclear weapons, rather than Mr. Trump's stance on the current policy, actually pertain to Mr. Trump's responsibility as a presidential candidate?

HOLT_94.intervention:
HOLT: "we 're talking about the burden that Americans have to pay , yet you have not released your tax returns
the reason nominees have released their returns for decades is so that voters will know if their potential president owes money to—who he owes it to and any business conflicts
Do n't Americans have a right to know if there are any conflicts of interest"

cqs.cq: Does the fact that nominees have released their tax returns for decades imply a general requirement on the part of presidential candidates to disclose this information?
Is it unfair to require a public figure's financial disclosure based solely on their office, rather than their individual actions or relationships?
Does the burden on the nominee to disclose their tax returns proportionally outweigh the potential benefits of transparency in conflict of interest information?

Helen__66.intervention:
Helen: "they’re not able to impose the right sort of levels
and within that bracket I would certainly put families who are living with very high levels of aggression and violence, who are terrorising communities
So, yes I’d agree with that
But I would also say that there are other families, where actually they do need a great deal of help
it’s right to intervene
and actually you can help them get back on their feet and able to parent their children effectively"

cqs.cq: Is it clear that intervening with families who are living with high levels of aggression and violence is justified when it may potentially displace or harm other families in need of support?
Does Helen's argument for intervening in families that need help not implicitly assume that the best intervention is always removal of the family from their environment?
How can we determine what constitutes a 'great deal of help' for a family, especially when it comes to addressing aggression and violence?

17th_knight__247.intervention:
17th: "They should get the coverage
They are here
they work
they are a part of this society
Fuck off with your xenophobia"
 < this message is answering to > 
reaper527: "now you have a field of democrat presidential candidates supporting it
republicans used to get mocked and laughed at when they said that illegal immigrants would be getting obamacare coverage"

cqs.cq: Does the fact that a certain political party is now supporting a particular policy necessarily imply its inherent legitimacy?

Is the validity of this argument about immigration policy being supported by a field of Democratic presidential candidates sufficient to counter the criticism that Republicans were mocked for similar views in the past?

Is the argument's claim that Republicans used to support providing Obamacare coverage to undocumented immigrants when they were the minority party a sufficient reason to justify their current stance on the issue?

AFCHF_154.intervention:
AFCHF: "DOT should set maximum tarmac delay trigger.
It then should apply to ALL AIRLINES and ALL CLASSES of AIRCRAFT.
The airlines need to make a legal committment (contract of carriage).
Deplaneing without CBP screening IS a viable option.
As a military member, I have done this many times during overseas contract flights.
I realize this is customs rather than airport security, but the concept is the same.
Allow passengers to deplane during gate holds,
but require them to remain in the immediate area.
This is no different than an openended delay prior to boarding."

cqs.cq: Does deplaning without CBP screening during gate holds not introduce a new safety risk that would necessitate separate security protocols?
Is it reasonable to assume that deplaning without CBP screening during a gate hold is equivalent to an open-ended delay prior to boarding, when the purpose and procedures for both differ?
How does deplaning without CBP screening during gate holds, as proposed, not pose a risk to national security and public safety?

AK-traveler_186.intervention:
AK-traveler: "Airlines should not be allowed to charge for items necessary because of factors out of the passengers control.
Seat size and configuration (arm and leg room) should be addressed as a health issue.
The inflight magazines show exercises passengers should do at their seats to prevent deep vein thrombosis
but there isn't enough room to do them.
And finally, I think it is unfair if not criminal and discriminatory to charge exorbinant fees for carrying your pet onboard with you.
The carrier is handled as a carry on bag solely by me,
the airline doesn't do anything
yet they carage $100 or more each way."

cqs.cq: Does not charging for necessary items with airline travel pose a greater risk to passengers' health and well-being than carrying pets, given that the latter can be managed with simple arrangements?
Is it reasonable to assume that airlines can control all factors related to passenger health and safety while charging for items outside of their control?
Does the airline's charging policy for carrying pets onboard not being a factor of their control or availability justify the imposition of exorbitant fees?

AllergyDad_200.intervention:
AllergyDad: "As a parent of a child with severe lifethreatening allergies to peanuts and treenuts, the thought of getting on an airplane today is frightening.
So much so, that it is strictly avoided.
It is not worth risking my child's life to fly on an airplane.
A recent study reveals that 1 in 3 airplane reactions was anaphylaxis
(Allergic Living Magazine).
I don't like those odds.
The substitution of cashews, walnuts, or other tree nuts is not a viable option,
as they pose the same risks as peanuts.
A large number of people who are allergic to peanuts are also allergic to tree nuts,
plus they are typically processed in a plant that also processes peanuts.
If there were a ban on peanut and tree nut products on flights, it would open the world to my son.
He didn't choose to be allergic,
but he is.
So true.
We are not talking about sensitivity, being offended, not liking the smell, etc.;
we are talking about life.
There are a lot of things that are banned from airplanes that can cause death to someone.
In the case of my son, a peanut can have the same result.
I urge the DOT to issue the ban,
and make traveling safe for everyone."

cqs.cq: Does the argument assume that a blanket ban on all peanuts and tree nuts would be an effective and proportionate solution to address the risk of allergic reactions on flights?

Does the author's conclusion that a blanket ban on peanuts and tree nuts is justified by the risk of anaphylaxis on flights solely based on a single study, when the same risks may apply to many other foods banned from airplanes?

Does the argument's conclusion that a ban on peanut and tree nut products is necessary to ensure the safety of individuals with severe allergies, given that many people who are allergic to peanuts are also allergic to tree nuts, justify the potential economic and social implications of such a ban?

AngelComa__638.intervention:
AngelComa: "Funny, I thought he did good
They get timed responses
his plan is all there
He can't talk about everything in the plan
Must be how used you are to politicians saying things and not having a plan"
 < this message is answering to > 
Punchee: "That was a weird moment in American debate history. "Yo check my website. Shit's on there.""

cqs.cq: Does Punchee's response constitute an admission of having no knowledge about AngelComa's plan, or is it merely a clever attempt to deflect criticism?
Is AngelComma assuming that Punchee is being inconsistent, or simply that Punchee's response is a rational reaction to an unclear situation?
Does Punchee's response imply that his plan is actually available for public scrutiny, or is he simply dismissing AngelComa's claims without addressing their substance?

Antanagoge_104.intervention:
Antanagoge: "The airline industry can not be left to selfmonitor this.
Studies have shown that the quality of information from airline customer service department is highly variable and, in some cases, incomplete or inaccurate.
The psychological effects of this, combined with the risk of death, are significant.
Stories told by families of vacations never taken, of midair retraction of the promise by the airline that peanuts would not be served, of public humiliation of peanutallergic individuals and their family by airline staff, and of serious reactions in flight, abound."

cqs.cq: How can we be certain that studies showing variable and inaccurate information from airline customer service departments are not also influenced by biases of the researchers or sources?
How can we be certain that the studies cited by Antanagoge are not being misinterpreted or taken out of context to support an anti-airline agenda?
Does Antanagoge provide sufficient evidence that the airline industry's inability to self-monitor is the sole or primary cause of these incidents?

Antanagoge_111.intervention:
Antanagoge: "The opponents of accommodations are well aware that studies have been published in the journals of the American Academy of Allergy Asthma and Immunology, the American Medical Association, and the American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology, not to mention medical associations in other countries.
They can purchase full text access for themselves,
but they already have a prejudgment against the researchers and their conclusions,
so why bother?
There was a moment on the board when the moderators asked for a discussion of a hypothetical compromise position.
But those demanding funerals before entertaining even a compromise position muted that.
That is sad.
There are several others on the board with some good reasonable ideas.
It's fairly clear that meanspiritedness abounds, here
probably as a result of emphasis in current American politics on the potential for influence of minority interests and needs.
But some of the people on this board  calling for funerals before advancing the discussion  give new meaning to the Founders' fears of the tyranny of the majority."

cqs.cq: Does Antanagoge's conclusion that opponents of accommodations are motivated solely by 'meanspiritedness' and a desire to silence opposing views rather than engage in rational discussion, accurately reflect the complexities of the debate?

Is it reasonable to assume that because one group has access to published research, they can objectively judge the conclusions of researchers with a prejudgment, and is this assumption not itself influenced by their existing biases?
Does Antanagoge's claim that those demanding funerals are motivated by a genuine concern for avoiding the influence of minority interests and needs, rather than mean-spiritedness, warrant scrutiny?

Antanagoge_227.intervention:
Antanagoge: "Peanut allergens are indeed present in the recirculated air in the aircraft cabin.
This study, "Recovery of peanut allergens from ventilation filters of commercial airliners," ? conducted "to help address whether peanutsensitive travelers are exposed to peanut aeroallergans during airline flights on which peanuts are served" ? resulted in the conclusion that "that peanut allergens can be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners. The most likely source of these allergens are the peanuts served during flights." ?
http://download.journals.elsevierhealth.com/pdfs/journals/00916749/PIIS0091674996811791.pdf"
 < this message is answering to > 
Mulder: "Apparently Samsmom is the ignorant one.
She attacks what she clearly does not understand.
If her child has a true peanut allergy that is so severe, he shouldn't be flying,
since her argument is that any contact with peanut dust or oil would cause anaphylactic shock.
Since that possibility is very real even outside an airline cabin,
she's making her own argument for living in a bubble.
Facts are stubborn things,
and one of those facts is that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings,
so there's very little, if any, real risk involved in flying on a jet where peanuts have been consumed before or are even being served now.
Another stubborn fact is that you can be desensitized to peanut allergies,
but if you're unwilling to do it, don't blame others for not bending to your petty fears.
Nobody has studied this subject,
so there's no hard data.
But we do know that the air onboard an airliner is much cleaner than people think.
Only one confirmed death onboard an airliner has been reported,
but it may have been as far back as 1998,
and it was an Eastern European airline."

cqs.cq: Does Mulder's argument assume that the absence of evidence for severe peanut allergy-related deaths on commercial airliners necessarily implies a lack of risk, or could other factors contribute to these incidents?

Does the argument that there is no risk involved in flying on a plane where peanuts have been consumed before or are being served now assume that the peanut allergen study's results can be applied directly to real-world flight scenarios?

Can we assume that the air quality on a commercial airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings solely based on the fact that there has only been one confirmed death onboard an aircraft, without considering potential indirect risks or uncertainties associated with peanutsensitive travelers?

Antanagoge_239.intervention:
Antanagoge: "Is it really possible that all blindly partisan advocates of the peanut in this context eat peanuts and only peanuts?
That they are overtaken by such a compulsion to consume peanut while flying that they lose sight of all other priorities?
That they are unable to stop using their peanut  the one dragon they can't put to sleep  to create a sense of pleasure and comfort?
These sound like essential symptoms of disordered eating and addiction, which, in all likelihood, derive from some longstanding issues.
The remedy is to avoid the substance in question.... "just say 'no'" ? to your peanuts.
Serving/eating peanuts on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace, as had tobacco smoking.
Again, the only prudent course of action is to require that distribution of peanut on airplanes be discontinued."
 < this message is answering to > 
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: Does Antanagoge's argument that serving peanuts on airplanes poses a public health menace actually account for the possibility of individuals having legitimate, medically-diagnosed peanut allergies?
Does the lack of documented cases of peanut-induced fatalities on planes adequately address the potential risks associated with peanut consumption during air travel?

Is it possible that dismissing the concerns about peanuts on airplanes solely because one can find no documented deaths from peanut-related allergic reactions ignores the possibility of other, potentially life-threatening reactions not captured in public health records?

Bill_106.intervention:
Bill: "I run a retail business.
If I changed my prices every few minutes or hours like the airline does or charge my customers different prices on the same day.
They would probably never come back and call the better business bureau.
And they wonder why so much distrust and angry customers.
Recently I wrote to one airline that had a ticket price of around $198. but then listed the taxes at something like $400.00 extra.
I told them it was Bait and Add on.
Similar to some retail stores that Bait customers with low price and then Switch to higher priced goods.
It is illegal and called Bait and Switch.
The airlines or some ticket sellers are guilty of lies.
Taxes are never higher than the price of the ticket.
I spend hours trying to buy a ticket without getting ripped off.
It should not be this difficult.
And one way fare should be half of a RT not higher than RT.
hey force us to buy RT and then use only the one way portion."

cqs.cq: Does Bill's experience as a retail business owner qualify him to make informed comments about airline ticket pricing and the practices of airlines?
Does Bill's conclusion that airlines are engaging in bait and switch tactics, leading to distrust among customers, logically follow from his own retail business experience?

Does Bill's claim that airlines engage in a widespread practice of baiting customers with lower ticket prices, only to increase them with additional fees, align with the actual practices of the airline industry?

CF_29.intervention:
CF: "Yes, but what I'm saying is we shouldn’t encourage it for ourselves either
That’s my point.
And then finally, if I could just ask you, there’s a danger I think when you kind of say, “The poor are the ones who suffer. The rich are the bad guys.”
It is the case that some of the greatest examples of social progress over the years have come from well-off rich people, banks and so on, investing productively
Isn’t the problem that the only thing the banks have done is kind of consumer credit?
What they should have been doing, what they could be doing, and what they haven’t got the nerve to do, is not loaning enough
They should actually be taking more risk and giving more money out"

cqs.cq: Doesn't the argument rely on an assumption that the role of rich individuals in social progress is equivalent to, or independent of, their ability and willingness to engage in socially impactful investments?
Does the argument's defense of capitalist institutions like banks relying on consumer credit to mitigate social problems not inadvertently legitimize and reinforce existing power structures?

Does the argument that rich individuals and institutions can be beneficial to society, as evidenced by their investment in productive endeavors, support the claim that they are the primary source of social problems?

CF_46.intervention:
CF: "Yes, but I'm suggesting that that was a political strategy, a way of covering things up
All I'm saying is that I think the people who took the sub-prime mortgages were the beneficiaries – and now the sufferers – of what I was saying is a policy
When you think about it now, I actually find it frustrating when I'm trying to talk to people about the real state the economy is in
And people sort of assume like everything can just carry on, and all that you need is a kind of credit based consumer thing
“Well, do we have to have cuts? Do we have to have this? Do we have to have that?”
And you do actually want to say, “Money doesn’t grow on trees.”"

cqs.cq: Does the critic's assertion that they were trying to highlight economic truths by criticizing a policy actually mask their own economic interests or ideological biases?
Is it possible that the speaker's frustration with others' assumptions about economic policy is being used to justify their own views on austerity?

Is it possible that the speaker's frustration with others assuming everything can continue without consequences is being used to justify or downplay the severity of the economic issues they were initially discussing?

CLINTON_103.intervention:
CLINTON: "I think you 've seen another example of bait-and- switch here
For 40 years , everyone running for president has released their tax returns
You can go and see nearly , I think , 39 , 40 years of our tax returns
everyone has done it
We know the IRS has made clear there is no prohibition on releasing it when you 're under audit
you 've got to ask yourself , why wo n't he release his tax returns ?
there may be a couple of reasons
First , maybe he 's not as rich as he says he is
Second , maybe he 's not as charitable as he claims to be
maybe he does n't want the American people , all of you watching tonight , to know that he 's paid nothing in federal taxes
the only years that anybody 's ever seen were a couple of years when he had to turn them over to state authorities when he was trying to get a casino license
they showed he did n't pay any federal income tax"

cqs.cq: Is it logically possible that a presidential candidate who has released nearly all of his tax returns for over three decades would deliberately withhold two or fewer years' worth of returns, citing an unrelated state audit, without raising any suspicions among the IRS?
Is Clinton's assumption that his tax returns would be publicly available if he had released them under audit necessarily true?

Does Clinton's assumption that Donald Trump has something to hide, based on an incomplete and potentially cherry-picked example from a few years, constitute reasonable grounds for questioning his tax returns?

CLINTON_123_1.intervention:
CLINTON: "Race remains a significant challenge in our country
Unfortunately, race still determines too much
often determines where people live
determines what kind of education in their public schools they can get,
it determines how they're treated in the criminal justice system
We've just seen those two tragic examples in both Tulsa and Charlotte
we've got to do several things at the same time
We have to restore trust between communities and the police
We have to work to make sure that our police are using the best training, the best techniques, that they're well prepared to use force only when necessary
Everyone should be respected by the law, and everyone should respect the law
Right now, that's not the case in a lot of our neighborhoods
I have, ever since the first day of my campaign, called for criminal justice reform"

cqs.cq: Does President Clinton's assertion that systemic racism affects every aspect of society, including education and treatment by law enforcement, remain unchanged despite his campaign promise to address only criminal justice reform?
Is it possible to say that race determines these factors (where people live, education quality, criminal justice treatment) without acknowledging other significant contributing factors?
Is it possible that the speaker's assertion that 'race still determines too much' is supported by evidence, or is this claim based on an anecdotal observation?

CLINTON_123_2.intervention:
CLINTON: "I've laid out a platform that I think would begin to remedy some of the problems we have in the criminal justice system
we also have to recognize, in addition to the challenges that we face with policing, there are so many good, brave police officers who equally want reform
we have to bring communities together in order to begin working on that as a mutual goal
we've got to get guns out of the hands of people who should not have them
The gun epidemic is the leading cause of death of young African- American men, more than the next nine causes put together
we have to do two things
We have to restore trust
We have to work with the police
We have to make sure they respect the communities and the communities respect them
we have to tackle the plague of gun violence
which is a big contributor to a lot of the problems that we're seeing today"

cqs.cq: How can Clinton's claim that the gun epidemic is the leading cause of death of young African-American men be supported by empirical evidence?
How does Clinton define and measure the success of reforming the criminal justice system, particularly with regards to the gun epidemic?
Does the argument that the gun epidemic is the leading cause of death of young African-American men provide sufficient evidence to justify the proposed policy of restricting access to guns?

CLINTON_130_1.intervention:
CLINTON: "I've heard Donald say this at his rallies
it's really unfortunate that he paints such a dire negative picture of black communities in our country
the vibrancy of the black church
the black businesses that employ so many people
the opportunities that so many families are working to provide for their kids
There's a lot that we should be proud of and we should be supporting and lifting up
we do always have to make sure we keep people safe
There are the right ways of doing it
then there are ways that are ineffective
Stop-and-frisk was found to be unconstitutional
in part, because it was ineffective
It did not do what it needed to do
I believe in community policing
in fact, violent crime is one-half of what it was in 1991
Property crime is down 40 percent
We just don't want to see it creep back up
We've had 25 years of very good cooperation
there were some problems
some unintended consequences
Too many young African-American and Latino men ended up in jail for nonviolent offenses"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's claim that certain policing methods are ineffective solely based on their inability to reduce crime rates, take into account other potential factors contributing to changes in crime rates?
Does Clinton's argument that stop-and-frisk was unconstitutional solely because it was ineffective, rather than for other reasons such as its disproportionate impact on minority communities?

Does Clinton's assertion that community policing is a proven and effective solution to addressing crime, based on the stated declines in violent and property crime rates, account for the disproportionate incarceration of young African-American and Latino men?

CLINTON_130_2.intervention:
CLINTON: "it's just a fact that if you're a young African-American man and you do the same thing as a young white man, you are more likely to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated
we've got to address the systemic racism in our criminal justice system
We cannot just say law and order
we have to come forward with a plan that is going to divert people from the criminal justice system
deal with mandatory minimum sentences, which have put too many people away for too long for doing too little
We need to have more second chance programs
I'm glad that we're ending private prisons in the federal system
I want to see them ended in the state system
You shouldn't have a profit motivation to fill prison cells with young Americans
here are some positive ways we can work on this
I believe strongly that commonsense gun safety measures would assist us
Right now—and this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby—right now, we've got too many military- style weapons on the streets
this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby
In a lot of places, our police are outgunned
We need comprehensive background checks
we need to keep guns out of the hands of those who will do harm
we finally need to pass a prohibition on anyone who's on the terrorist watch list from being able to buy a gun in our country
If you're too dangerous to fly, you are too dangerous to buy a gun
there are things we can do
we ought to do it in a bipartisan way"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's claim that young African-American men are more likely to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated due to systemic racism in the criminal justice system, rather than any difference in behavior, hold up under scrutiny of empirical evidence?
Does Clinton's assertion that addressing systemic racism in the criminal justice system requires commonsense gun safety measures be supported by empirical evidence?
How does Senator Clinton's proposal for commonsense gun safety measures reconcile with her past support from the gun lobby, as stated by Donald?

CLINTON_147.intervention:
CLINTON: "New York has done an excellent job
I give credit across the board going back two mayors, two police chiefs
it has worked
other communities need to come together to do what will work
one murder is too many
it is important that we learn about what has been effective
not go to things that sound good that really did not have the kind of impact that we would want
Who disagrees with keeping neighborhoods safe
no one should disagree about respecting the rights of young men who live in those neighborhoods
we need to do a better job of working, again, with the communities, faith communities, business communities, as well as the police to try to deal with this problem"

cqs.cq: Does Mayor Clinton's assertion that increased community engagement and collaboration are the sole solutions to reducing murder rates, while neglecting to mention any concrete policy initiatives or evidence-based strategies, demonstrate a reasonable approach to addressing crime?

Does Clinton's claim that other communities need to 'come together' to address crime effectively, without specifying what particular actions or policies this would entail, provide a coherent and actionable plan for reducing murder rates?

Does Clinton's emphasis on learning from New York's experiences and involving multiple community groups necessarily imply that there are already effective solutions available elsewhere, rather than simply providing another example of what has worked?

CLINTON_17.intervention:
CLINTON: "let 's stop for a second and remember where we were eight years ago
We had the worst financial crisis , the Great Recession
the worst since the 1930s
 slashed taxes on the wealthy
failed to invest in the middle class
took their eyes off of Wall Street
created a perfect storm
was in large part because of tax policies
Donald was one of the people who rooted for the housing crisis
...
 it did collapse"

cqs.cq: Is Clinton's assertion that the Great Recession was solely caused by his tax policies supported by evidence from economists who specialize in recessions, or is it based on a selective interpretation of historical data?
What is the relationship between Clinton's assertion that the Great Recession was caused by tax policies and the specific tax policies he proposes to implement as part of his economic plan?
Does Clinton's assertion that the Great Recession was solely caused by tax policies on the wealthy and neglect of Wall Street ignore other potential contributing factors?

CLINTON_176_1.intervention:
CLINTON: "cyber security, cyber warfare will be one of the biggest challenges facing the next president
clearly we're facing at this point two different kinds of adversaries
There are the independent hacking groups that do it mostly for commercial reasons to try to steal information that they can use to make money
increasingly, we are seeing cyber attacks coming from states, organs of states
The most recent and troubling of these has been Russia
There's no doubt now that Russia has used cyber attacks against all kinds of organizations in our country
I am deeply concerned about this
Donald's very praiseworthy of Vladimir Putin
Putin is playing a really tough, long game here
one of the things he's done is to let loose cyber attackers to hack into government files, to hack into personal files, hack into the Democratic National Committee"

cqs.cq: Is it reasonable to assume that Russia's cyber attacks are solely motivated by a desire to hack into government and personal files, or could they also be driven by other strategic interests?
Is it reasonable to assume that Russia's actions are motivated solely by a desire for financial gain, given their publicly stated admiration and support of President Trump?

Is the concern about Russian cyber attacks sufficient to justify labeling Vladimir Putin's actions as a 'tough, long game' when no clear evidence of malicious intent or strategic national interest is presented?

CLINTON_176_2.intervention:
CLINTON: "we recently have learned that, you know, that this is one of their preferred methods of trying to wreak havoc and collect information
We need to make it very clear—whether it's Russia, China, Iran or anybody else—the United States has much greater capacity
we are not going to sit idly by and permit state actors to go after our information, our private-sector information or our public-sector information
 we're going to have to make it clear that we don't want to use the kinds of tools that we have
We don't want to engage in a different kind of warfare
we will defend the citizens of this country
 the Russians need to understand that
 they've been treating it as almost a probing, how far would we go, how much would we do
I was so shocked when Donald publicly invited Putin to hack into Americans
That is just unacceptable"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's assertion that Russia has publicly invited Putin to hack into Americans, as implied by 'Donald publicly invited Putin to hack into Americans', actually occur in a credible and verifiable source?
Does the President's statement that the Russians need to understand that they cannot hack into Americans constitute a credible threat, or is it simply an empty warning?

Does the United States have a compelling evidence-based justification for taking action against Russia's alleged hacking activities, rather than relying on accusations and assertions from a former President?

CLINTON_186.intervention:
CLINTON: "there are a number of issues that we should be addressing
I have put forth a plan to defeat ISIS
It does involve going after them online
we need to do much more with our tech companies to prevent ISIS and their operatives from being able to use the Internet to radicalize , even direct people in our country and Europe and elsewhere
eventually support our Arab and Kurdish partners to be able to actually take out ISIS in Raqqa
end their claim of being a Caliphate
We 're making progress
Our military is assisting in Iraq
we 're hoping that within the year we 'll be able to push ISIS out of Iraq
really squeeze them in Syria
we have to be cognizant of the fact that they 've had foreign fighters coming to volunteer for them
foreign money
foreign weapons
we have to make this the top priority
I would also do everything possible to take out their leadership
I was involved in a number of efforts to take out Al Qaida leadership when I was secretary of state
including , of course , taking out bin Laden
we need to go after Baghdadi , as well
make that one of our organizing principles
we 've got to defeat ISIS
we 've got to do everything we can to disrupt their propaganda efforts online"

cqs.cq: How does Clinton's plan to defeat ISIS specifically address the concern of ISIS's online recruitment efforts, rather than simply monitoring and tracking them?
How does Clinton's plan to defeat ISIS account for the potential unintended consequences of limiting online freedom and free speech, potentially harming innocent civilians or Western societies?

Does Clinton's plan to defeat ISIS rely solely on military action, or does it also account for the potential consequences of online radicalization and the need for a comprehensive strategy that includes economic and diplomatic elements?

CLINTON_193.intervention:
CLINTON: "I hope the fact-checkers are turning up the volume and really working hard
Donald supported the invasion of Iraq
...
That is absolutely proved over and over again
...
He actually advocated for the actions we took in Libya
urged that Gadhafi be taken out
after actually doing some business with him one time
larger point—and he says this constantly—is George W. Bush made the agreement about when American troops would leave Iraq , not Barack Obama
 the only way that American troops could have stayed in Iraq is to get an agreement from the then-Iraqi government that would have protected our troops
the Iraqi government would not give that
let 's talk about the question you asked , Lester"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's statement that he made a deal with Gaddafi one time constitute sufficient evidence to validate his claim about Bush not making the agreement about when American troops would leave Iraq?

Does Clinton's claim that American troops would have had to get an agreement from the then-Iraqi government to stay in Iraq necessarily imply that Obama, as President, could not have negotiated such an agreement?

Is it possible that Clinton's claims of Bush not securing an agreement for the withdrawal of American troops from Iraq are based solely on his own interpretation or bias, rather than a verifiable record?

CLINTON_199_1.intervention:
CLINTON: "That's the most important part of this
How do we prevent attacks
How do we protect our people
we've got to have an intelligence surge, where we are looking for every scrap of information
I was so proud of law enforcement in New York, in Minnesota, in New Jersey
 they responded so quickly, so professionally to the attacks that occurred by Rahami
they brought him down
we may find out more information
 he is still alive"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's statement about Rahami being 'still alive' contradict his earlier claim that law enforcement had 'brought him down'?
Does Clinton's argument that an intelligence surge is necessary solely based on his pride in law enforcement's response to a specific incident provide sufficient justification for such a measure?

Does Clinton's claim about being proud of law enforcement responding quickly to the attacks imply that their quick response was solely due to their own efforts, rather than any intelligence gathered from the alleged 'intelligence surge'?

TRUMP_240_2.intervention:
TRUMP: "by the way , another one powerful is the worst deal I think I 've ever seen negotiated that you started is the Iran deal
Iran is one of their biggest trading partners
Iran has power over North Korea
when they made that horrible deal with Iran , they should have included the fact that they do something with respect to North Korea
they should have done something with respect to Yemen and all these other places

obviously , I guess for the hostages

you say to yourself , why did n't they make the right deal ?

cqs.cq: How does Trump's criticism of the Iran deal, specifically regarding its impact on North Korea and other countries, accurately account for the numerous diplomatic and intelligence efforts undertaken by the US during the negotiations with Iran?
Does the criticism of the Iran deal's omission of discussions about North Korea and Yemen imply that those issues are directly connected to the deal's outcome?
Does Trump's criticism of the Iran deal solely focus on its alleged shortcomings, or does he ignore or downplay the numerous benefits and achievements of the agreement?

TRUMP_249.intervention:

I will tell you that Hillary will tell you to go to her website and read all about how to defeat ISIS

get going in the first place

they 're in more and more places
more and more states
more and more nations

we are losing billions and billions of dollars

cqs.cq: Does Trump's claim that Hillary's approach to defeating ISIS would have prevented the problem from arising in the first place, taking into account the complexities of international relations and counter-terrorism strategies?
Does Trump's claim that Hillary's approach to defeating ISIS is the main reason for its growing threat level, rather than any actual military or strategic failures under his own leadership?
Is it logically consistent for Trump to claim that ISIS would have been defeated if Hillary had never given rise to it, yet simultaneously acknowledge the growing threat posed by ISIS?

TRUMP_251.intervention:

she 's got no business ability
We need heart

you have to have some basic ability
sadly , she does n't have that
All of the things that she 's talking about could have been taken care of during the last 10 years , let 's say , while she had great power
they were n't taken care of
if she ever wins this race , they wo n't be taken care of

...
she does n't say that"

cqs.cq: Does Trump's criticism of Biden's ability to pay workers and his lack of a 'presidential look' constitute a meaningful evaluation of Biden's qualifications, or is it merely an attack based on personal opinion and bias?

Is Trump's characterization of Biden's policy proposals based solely on their perceived 'ability' to be implemented during his previous term in office, rather than any actual assessment of their merits or effectiveness?
Does Trump's assertion that the Democratic candidate lacks basic ability solely based on their party affiliation constitute a valid evaluation of their qualifications for the presidency?

TRUMP_253.intervention:
TRUMP: "She does n't have the look
She does n't have the stamina
I said she does n't have the stamina
I do n't believe she does have the stamina
To be president of this country , you need tremendous stamina
I just do n't think she has the presidential look
You asked me a question
You have to be able to negotiate our trade deals
You have to be able to negotiate , that 's right , with Japan , with Saudi Arabia
All you have to do is speak to them
Wait
...
Did you ask me a question
can you imagine , we 're defending Saudi Arabia
with all of the money they have , we 're defending them , and they 're not paying
You have so many different things you have to be able to do , and I do n't believe that Hillary has the stamina
The world
Hillary has experience , but it 's bad experience
it 's bad , bad experience
it 's the Iran deal that you 're so in love with , where we gave them $ 150 billion back
it 's the Iran deal
it 's anything you can—name
you almost ca n't name a good deal
She 's got experience , but it 's bad experience"

cqs.cq: Does Trump's claim that Hillary lacks 'tremendous stamina' to be president, a criterion he himself has emphasized as necessary for the job, remain consistent with his own demonstrated ability to negotiate with powerful nations like Japan and Saudi Arabia?

Does Trump's assertion that Hillary Clinton lacks stamina and presidential 'look' constitute a reasonable evaluation of her qualifications for the presidency, given his own lack of experience in foreign policy and trade negotiation?

Does Trump's assertion that Hillary lacks stamina to be president, despite his own admission that negotiating trade deals with Japan and Saudi Arabia requires strong communication skills, not stamina?

TRUMP_26.intervention:
TRUMP: "She talks about solar panels
We invested in a solar company , our country
That was a disaster
They lost plenty of money on that one
I 'm a great believer in all forms of energy
we 're putting a lot of people out of work
Our energy policies are a disaster
Our country is losing so much in terms of energy
 in terms of paying off our debt
You ca n't do what you 're looking to do with $ 20 trillion in debt
The Obama administration , from the time they 've come in , is over 230 years ' worth of debt
he 's topped it
He 's doubled it in a course of almost eight years
seven-and-a-half years , to be semi- exact
We have to do a much better job at keeping our jobs
we have to do a much better job at giving companies incentives to build new companies or to expand
they 're not doing it
all you have to do is look at Michigan and look at Ohio and look at all of these places where so many of their jobs and their companies are just leaving
they 're gone
You 've been doing this for 30 years
Why are you just thinking about these solutions right now ?
For 30 years , you 've been doing it
now you 're just starting to think of solutions
I will bring back jobs
You ca n't bring back jobs"

cqs.cq: Does Trump's assertion that he has been thinking about solutions for 30 years to bring back jobs, given his long history of dismissing and opposing such policies, not qualify as a rational response?

Does Trump's criticism of Obama's energy policies and his claim that he can bring back jobs more effectively than Obama are based on a fair comparison, given the vastly different economic conditions and policies in place during their respective presidencies?
Does Trump's criticism of solar panels and his energy policies remain based on their actual effects, rather than being driven by personal opinion or nostalgia for the past?

TRUMP_275.intervention:
TRUMP: "Hillary is hitting me with tremendous commercials
Some of it 's said in entertainment
Some of it 's said
somebody who 's been very vicious to me , Rosie O'Donnell
I said very tough things to her
everybody would agree that she deserves it
nobody feels sorry for her
you want to know the truth ?
I was going to say something
I was going to say something extremely rough to Hillary
to her family
I can't do it
I just can't do it
It's inappropriate
It's not nice
she spent hundreds of millions of dollars on negative ads on me
many of which are absolutely untrue
They're untrue
they're misrepresentations
I don't deserve that
it's certainly not a nice thing that she's done
It's hundreds of millions of ads
I've spent practically nothing"

cqs.cq: Does Trump's characterization of his own conduct as 'extremely rough' not be inconsistent with his criticism of Rosie O'Donnell for being 'very vicious to him'?

Does Trump's characterization of his advertising expenditure as 'practically nothing' given that he also accused Hillary of spending 'hundreds of millions of dollars on negative ads on me' accurately reflect the factual comparison between their respective ad expenditures?

Is it reasonable to conclude that the amount and nature of negative advertising one engages in justifies a response involving personal attacks, especially when such responses are described as 'extremely rough'?

TRUMP_279.intervention:
TRUMP: "I want to make America great again
We are a nation that is seriously troubled
We 're losing our jobs
People are pouring into our country
The other day , we were deporting 800 people
perhaps they passed the wrong button
they pressed the wrong button
perhaps worse than that
it was corruption
these people that we were going to deport for good reason ended up becoming citizens
Ended up becoming citizens
it was 800
now it turns out it might be 1,800
they do n't even know"

cqs.cq: Does Trump's assumption that immigrants who were deported or became citizens are somehow indicative of a widespread problem with his deportation policies, rather than just individual mistakes or exceptions?
Is Trump's claim that deporting individuals who eventually became citizens is a sign of corruption rather than incompetence or mistake supported by evidence?
How can the speaker reconcile the statement that these individuals were being deported for a 'good reason' with their subsequent admission that they ended up becoming citizens?

TRUMP_3_1.intervention:
TRUMP: "Our jobs are fleeing the country
They 're going to Mexico
They 're going to many other countries
You look at what China is doing to our country in terms of making our product
They 're devaluing their currency
there 's nobody in our government to fight them
we have a very good fight
we have a winning fight
they 're using our country as a piggy bank to rebuild China
many other countries are doing the same thing
we 're losing our good jobs , so many of them
When you look at what 's happening in Mexico , a friend of mine who builds plants said it 's the eighth wonder of the world
They 're building some of the biggest plants anywhere in the world , some of the most sophisticated , some of the best plants
With the United States , as he said , not so much
So Ford is leaving
You see that , their small car division leaving
Thousands of jobs leaving Michigan , leaving Ohio
They 're all leaving"

cqs.cq: Does Mr. Trump's claim that jobs are fleeing to other countries solely due to those countries devaluing their currency, and not because of the complex interplay of factors such as trade agreements, technological advancements, and the global economic landscape, accurately reflect the situation?

Does Trump's claim that other countries, particularly Mexico and China, are stealing American jobs without contributing to their own economies through trade or investment have been supported by credible evidence?

Does Trump's assertion that Mexico and other countries are directly responsible for American companies leaving the country, rather than any economic or market forces, accurately reflect the complex causes of job loss in the US?
